feed.title: Outgoing Reputation: Simulation Results and Updates

entry.title: Outgoing Reputation: Simulation Results and Updates
entry.summary:
A concern was raised regarding the potential for attackers to manipulate the reputation system in Lightning Network protocols, specifically targeting the mechanism by which reputations are calculated based on response times to payment requests. The mechanism under scrutiny allows for a 90-second window for replies; however, an attacker could exploit this by timing their responses such that they reply within the window while causing the next node in the sequence to exceed this limit due to inherent network delays. This tactic would unfairly penalize the honest nodeâ€™s reputation while leaving the attacker's reputation unscathed.
Upon closer examination of this scenario, it becomes evident that for an attacker to significantly impact an honest node's reputation, they would need to engage in behavior that not only outpaces the natural flow of legitimate payments but also incurs substantial costs. An analysis, albeit simplistic and optimistic from the attacker's perspective, revealed that even if an attacker were to push 500 hash time-locked contracts (HTLCs) through a single channel, assuming the channel processes an average of 85 honest payments daily, the impact on the node's reputation would be minimal. Specifically, the reduction in reputation would be less than 2%, with the attacker incurring more than three times the cost in fees. Therefore, the conclusion reached is that such an attack would not be viable in practice. This finding underscores the resilience of the network's design against manipulation tactics, including those resembling quick jamming strategies, especially when taking into account the deterrent effect of upfront fees. For individuals interested in delving deeper into the specifics of these calculations, further details can be found [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1V0h7rrnEgrLbFvwq1DeLP0--pB9_DkWpKkg-3lfx_9Q/edit?usp=sharing).
